pull_request.title: Components index + Storybook source link addon
pull_request.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes a single source of truth for our official [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which in turn powers links to and between the documentation and Storybook. ### Storybook In #117 we added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. This PR includes a custom Storybook addon that populate's a story's `sourceLink` [parameters] from entries in the component index. Currently matches are made when the story's id (e.g. `components-button--primary`) matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern (e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons), but we could be more explicit about it. If this approach turns out to be difficult or unwieldy in any way, I'm happy to nix the addon and move to using inline `sourceLink` hrefs in our code. ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: As you can see from that page, I have not yet: 1. Proposed or defined any of the values for the component "Status" column 2. Moved the Figma links into the component index ⚠️ **There are other ways to do this!** For instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter.; and/or we could link to the docs from story [parameters] and parse those out from Docusaurus. But both of those approaches are trickier to build and maintain, I think, and having a centralized list lets us do things like ensure that all of the URLs exist in the docs and stories get generated at build time, so we could (theoretically) fail a CI build if we break a component link. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

issue.title: use tailwind safelist
issue.body:
we're trying to update our current theme build to include its own tailwind config to take the design system's preset and extend it in #1429 

tailwind's internal purge is removing all the safelisted patterns before our own purgeCSS does its thing.  tailwind used to have a `purge: false` option, [but it sounds like the `purge` option for tailwind 3 has been changed to `content` and only takes an array of glob patterns for tailwind's internal purge](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/upgrade-guide#configure-content-sources) (not 100% on this 😅 ).

[there is a `safelist` option](https://purgecss.com/safelisting.html), though, so this pr takes the purgeCss safelist and drops it in the tailwind config to honor that safelist

comment.body:
Yeah, we need to look at this more closely. I didn't realize that in Tailwind 3 they've dropped PurgeCSS, so we might actually want to downgrade to 2.x and pass the purge config as I suggested in the other PR. That has a kinda funky smell to me, though, since the "outer" PurgeCSS plugin _should_ be removing all of the things we don't use and that aren't in our safelist.

Before we make any more changes, though, can you figure out which new utilities are the source of this ballooning in size? [cssstats-diff](https://www.npmjs.com/package/cssstats-diff) might help with this:

```sh
npx cssstats-diff path/to/old/utilities.css path/to/new/utilities.css
```

comment.body:
> @shawnbot there's some huge savings on the file size which made me wonder if we were missing utilities. but the pr screenshots look fine. the diff between what `develop` generates vs this pr says that lots of margin utils have been removed (like `m-12`, `m-16`, along with a bunch of others), but after a quick search in the templates, it doesn't look like those utils are being used. i could use a pairing session a sanity check 😅

I noticed that too! I think we need to look more closely at the diff, because I have a hunch those are the utilities we safelisted in the "outer" purge config. I left a suggestion that should test that theory.

pull_request.title: Bump parse-url and @lerna-lite/core
pull_request.body:
Bumps [parse-url](https://github.com/IonicaBizau/parse-url) and [@lerna-lite/core](https://github.com/ghiscoding/lerna-lite/tree/HEAD/packages/core). These dependencies needed to be updated together. Updates `parse-url` from 7.0.2 to 8.1.0
Release notes

Sourced from parse-url's releases.

8.1.0

parse-url@8.1.0

  • fix: cjs to load normalize-url /cc #58
  • fix: Include index.d.ts in package.json /cc #63
  • feat: support custom SSH username /cc #60
  • feat: improve regex pattern /cc #59

Thanks to @​privatenumber and @​briancoit for their contributions! :cake:

8.0.0

parse-url 8.0.0

Breaking Changes

  • The resource property will not contain the port, but the host one will.
  • Throw an error if the input is invalid. Hence, file paths like /home/path/to/dir will only be valid if the file:// protocol is added (file://home/path/to/dir)
  • Throw an error if the input length exceeds the maximum length (parse.MAX_URL_LENGTH), by default 2048.

Fixes

  • fix file protocol spoofing #48, thanks @​vovikhangcdv!
  • fix: support hyphens in git@ URLs (#50) #51, thanks @​crenshaw-dev!
  • fix: support dot in git@ URLS #52, thanks @​GalHalupSeaLights!

Other changes

  • build: add CommonJS distribution thanks to @​privatenumber! /cc #54 :cake:

1.11.0 (2022-08-19)

Release info

You can now take advantage of Lerna-Lite JSON Schema to help with all available options of the lib and also validate your configs by simply adding the following line to your lerna.json file: "$schema": "node_modules/@lerna-lite/cli/schemas/lerna-schema.json". After that, hovering over any of the option will provide you with a quick detail of the option and the acceptable value(s)

comment.body:
For future reference: this was deploying (building on Heroku) as of f834f58, but stopped working after that. On the Actions side, I got as far as installing the `turbo-linux-64` optional dependency that Turbo needs to run in ubuntu, but at some point Turbo lost the plot and fails in the [`ci:build` script](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/b2ffad31caed7e42ac30bf6bd48333b88435a063/package.json#L15) with:

```
run failed: error preparing engine: the given task has not been registered
```

🤷

issue.title: POC: components index
issue.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes two different solutions on the Storybook side, and a single solution with a couple of implementation options for Docusaurus. ### Storybook 1. I've added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. 2. I stubbed out a custom Storybook addon that provides a "Docs" panel and shows a link to the corresponding component documentation if it finds a component with a matching story identifier: If no matching component is found for the story, it shows a message explaining how to link one: 👉 **I would love feedback on which of these is preferable.** IMO the panel is a bit clunky, but the source link button is far from obvious, so I'm not leaning toward either. I'm also open to other suggestions! ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: The "Docs" panel and the "All components" page both use the same [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which I'm proposing here as a single source of truth for the component. There are other ways we could do this; for instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter. 👉 **I would love feedback on this table and what it should include.** Regardless of how we do it, I'm trying to get at the idea of a central component index that links to all of the different things about that component: its written documentation, Storybook stories, Figma designs, source code, et al. It's quite possible in Storybook to write an addon that would automatically populate a story's [parameters] from entries in the component index using the same logic as the "Docs" panel addon I've made here; we would just need to agree on how those connections are made. (In this PR they're based on whether the story's id, e.g. `components-button--primary`, matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern, e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons.) [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

comment.body: Okay, so @coreyhunt and @jacksongonzales have agreed that the sourcelink addon is the way to go. I'm going to scrap the custom addon and figure out how to connect the component index with the sourcelink plugin.

pull_request.title: Stub out component stories with Figma links
pull_request.body:
This addresses both DESSYS-245 (skeleton) and DESSYS-239 (Figma designs in Storybook). Check it out:

[👀  Storybook](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/)

I've attempted to stub out all of the components in [this Figma file](https://www.figma.com/file/nCDNClTAztpLol9l74QWSP/Design-System-Components?node-id=5895%3A3405), grouped by page when appropriate and with form-specific components nested separately. I took the liberty of implementing a couple of stories just to get a feel for the workflow:

- All of the [Alerts & Banners](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-alerts-banners--banner)
- All of our [Buttons](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-buttons--primary-button) with a table layout showing the matrix of (inline | block) × (rest | hover/focus)
- A few simple [Containers](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-containers--disclaimer)
- An [Icon component](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-icons--icon)
- [Keyboard instructions](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-keyboard--kbd)
- [Tiles](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-tiles--event-tile) were a lot of fun

### Linting challenges
One big issue is JavaScript linting (with ESLint), and it's a weird two-fer:

* In VS Code, ESLint doesn't appear to respect either the React plugin and/or Babel config, because the linter won't parse JSX files — it bails on each file with the (sadly, familiar) error:
    > Parsing error: This experimental syntax requires enabling one of the following parser plugin(s): "jsx", "flow", "typescript". (42:70)

    What this means is that we don't get proper linting or auto-formatting in Storybook sources, which stiiiinks. I think it might come down where ESLint is running in VS Code, because I get this error when I run `eslint  storybook/stories/**/*.jsx` from the project root but _not_ when running it from within the `storybook` directory. It might mean having to set `root: true` in `storybook/.eslintrc.js` and configuring it manually there rather than inheriting the root config.

* In GitHub Actions, `npm run lint` from the project root works just fine (!!), but ESLint flags the `sfgov-design-system` imports in Storybook with `import/no-unresolved` errors. I've worked around this by downgrading that rule to a warning. This is super confusing because `sfgov-design-system` _does_ get symlinked to `/node_modules` by npm in both environments and Storybook builds just fine. This seems like less of an issue than what's going on in VS Code.

Together, these issues make it hard to catch issues before you push to GitHub. ☹️

issue.title: BREAKING CHANGE: update breakpoints, add xs + sm
issue.body: This PR implements @coreyhunt's suggested breakpoints in DESSYS-133. It's a breaking change because it modifies existing breakpoints. Here's how it will shake out, version-wise: name | now (>=3) | 2.x :--- | :--- | :--- `xs` | `375px` `sm` | `640px` `md` | `768px` | `420px` `lg` | `1024px` | `768px` `xl` | `1280px` | `1090px` In other words, all of the old breakpoints are now larger, with `md` growing to `lg`'s old size. The following breakpoints are new. I made [this CodePen](https://codepen.io/shawnbot/pen/dyeLaoQ) to show the differences:

comment.body: Once again (as noted in #116), there doesn't appear to be a difference in the size of the generated CSS. This is clearly not right because we have two new breakpoints, which should add a slew of new utility variants. 🤨

pull_request.title: POC: components index
pull_request.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes two different solutions, both branched from the Storybook stubbing in #117: 1. I've added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. 2. I stubbed out a custom Storybook addon that provides a "Docs" panel and shows a link to the corresponding component documentation if it finds a component with a matching story identifier: If no matching component is found for the story, it shows a message explaining how to link one: On the docs side, I've set up an "All components" page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

pull_request.title: Components index + Storybook source link addon
pull_request.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes a single source of truth for our official [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which in turn powers links to and between the documentation and Storybook. ### Storybook In #117 we added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. This PR includes a custom Storybook addon that populate's a story's `sourceLink` [parameters] from entries in the component index. Currently matches are made when the story's id (e.g. `components-button--primary`) matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern (e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons), but we could be more explicit about it. If this approach turns out to be difficult or unwieldy in any way, I'm happy to nix the addon and move to using inline `sourceLink` hrefs in our code. ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: As you can see from that page, I have not yet: 1. Proposed or defined any of the values for the component "Status" column 2. Moved the Figma links into the component index ⚠️ **There are other ways to do this!** For instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter.; and/or we could link to the docs from story [parameters] and parse those out from Docusaurus. But both of those approaches are trickier to build and maintain, I think, and having a centralized list lets us do things like ensure that all of the URLs exist in the docs and stories get generated at build time, so we could (theoretically) fail a CI build if we break a component link. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

Currently matches are made when the story's id (e.g. `components-button--primary`) matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern (e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons), but we could be more explicit about it. If this approach turns out to be difficult or unwieldy in any way, I'm happy to nix the addon and move to using inline `sourceLink` hrefs in our code. ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: As you can see from that page, I have not yet: 1. Proposed or defined any of the values for the component "Status" column 2. Moved the Figma links into the component index ⚠️ **There are other ways to do this!** For instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter.; and/or we could link to the docs from story [parameters] and parse those out from Docusaurus. But both of those approaches are trickier to build and maintain, I think, and having a centralized list lets us do things like ensure that all of the URLs exist in the docs and stories get generated at build time, so we could (theoretically) fail a CI build if we break a component link. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

issue.title: use tailwind safelist
issue.body:
we're trying to update our current theme build to include its own tailwind config to take the design system's preset and extend it in #1429 

tailwind's internal purge is removing all the safelisted patterns before our own purgeCSS does its thing.  tailwind used to have a `purge: false` option, [but it sounds like the `purge` option for tailwind 3 has been changed to `content` and only takes an array of glob patterns for tailwind's internal purge](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/upgrade-guide#configure-content-sources) (not 100% on this 😅 ).

[there is a `safelist` option](https://purgecss.com/safelisting.html), though, so this pr takes the purgeCss safelist and drops it in the tailwind config to honor that safelist

comment.body:
Yeah, we need to look at this more closely. I didn't realize that in Tailwind 3 they've dropped PurgeCSS, so we might actually want to downgrade to 2.x and pass the purge config as I suggested in the other PR. That has a kinda funky smell to me, though, since the "outer" PurgeCSS plugin _should_ be removing all of the things we don't use and that aren't in our safelist.

Before we make any more changes, though, can you figure out which new utilities are the source of this ballooning in size? [cssstats-diff](https://www.npmjs.com/package/cssstats-diff) might help with this:

```sh
npx cssstats-diff path/to/old/utilities.css path/to/new/utilities.css
```

pull_request.title: Bump parse-url and @lerna-lite/core
pull_request.body:
Bumps [parse-url](https://github.com/IonicaBizau/parse-url) and [@lerna-lite/core](https://github.com/ghiscoding/lerna-lite/tree/HEAD/packages/core). These dependencies needed to be updated together. Updates `parse-url` from 7.0.2 to 8.1.0
Release notes

Sourced from parse-url's releases.

8.1.0

parse-url@8.1.0

  • fix: cjs to load normalize-url /cc #58
  • fix: Include index.d.ts in package.json /cc #63
  • feat: support custom SSH username /cc #60
  • feat: improve regex pattern /cc #59

Thanks to @​privatenumber and @​briancoit for their contributions! :cake:

8.0.0

parse-url 8.0.0

Breaking Changes

  • The resource property will not contain the port, but the host one will.
  • Throw an error if the input is invalid. Hence, file paths like /home/path/to/dir will only be valid if the file:// protocol is added (file://home/path/to/dir)
  • Throw an error if the input length exceeds the maximum length (parse.MAX_URL_LENGTH), by default 2048.

Fixes

  • fix file protocol spoofing #48, thanks @​vovikhangcdv!
  • fix: support hyphens in git@ URLs (#50) #51, thanks @​crenshaw-dev!
  • fix: support dot in git@ URLS #52, thanks @​GalHalupSeaLights!

Other changes

  • build: add CommonJS distribution thanks to @​privatenumber! /cc #54 :cake:

comment.body:
For future reference: this was deploying (building on Heroku) as of f834f58, but stopped working after that. On the Actions side, I got as far as installing the `turbo-linux-64` optional dependency that Turbo needs to run in ubuntu, but at some point Turbo lost the plot and fails in the [`ci:build` script](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/b2ffad31caed7e42ac30bf6bd48333b88435a063/package.json#L15) with:

```
run failed: error preparing engine: the given task has not been registered
```

🤷

issue.title: POC: components index
issue.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes two different solutions on the Storybook side, and a single solution with a couple of implementation options for Docusaurus. ### Storybook 1. I've added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. 2. I stubbed out a custom Storybook addon that provides a "Docs" panel and shows a link to the corresponding component documentation if it finds a component with a matching story identifier: If no matching component is found for the story, it shows a message explaining how to link one: 👉 **I would love feedback on which of these is preferable.** IMO the panel is a bit clunky, but the source link button is far from obvious, so I'm not leaning toward either. I'm also open to other suggestions! ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: The "Docs" panel and the "All components" page both use the same [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which I'm proposing here as a single source of truth for the component. There are other ways we could do this; for instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter. 👉 **I would love feedback on this table and what it should include.** Regardless of how we do it, I'm trying to get at the idea of a central component index that links to all of the different things about that component: its written documentation, Storybook stories, Figma designs, source code, et al. It's quite possible in Storybook to write an addon that would automatically populate a story's [parameters] from entries in the component index using the same logic as the "Docs" panel addon I've made here; we would just need to agree on how those connections are made. (In this PR they're based on whether the story's id, e.g. `components-button--primary`, matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern, e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons.) [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

comment.body: Okay, so @coreyhunt and @jacksongonzales have agreed that the sourcelink addon is the way to go. I'm going to scrap the custom addon and figure out how to connect the component index with the sourcelink plugin.

pull_request.title: Stub out component stories with Figma links
pull_request.body:
This addresses both DESSYS-245 (skeleton) and DESSYS-239 (Figma designs in Storybook). Check it out:

[👀  Storybook](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/)

I've attempted to stub out all of the components in [this Figma file](https://www.figma.com/file/nCDNClTAztpLol9l74QWSP/Design-System-Components?node-id=5895%3A3405), grouped by page when appropriate and with form-specific components nested separately. I took the liberty of implementing a couple of stories just to get a feel for the workflow:

- All of the [Alerts & Banners](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-alerts-banners--banner)
- All of our [Buttons](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-buttons--primary-button) with a table layout showing the matrix of (inline | block) × (rest | hover/focus)
- A few simple [Containers](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-containers--disclaimer)
- An [Icon component](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-icons--icon)
- [Keyboard instructions](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-keyboard--kbd)
- [Tiles](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-tiles--event-tile) were a lot of fun

### Linting challenges
One big issue is JavaScript linting (with ESLint), and it's a weird two-fer:

* In VS Code, ESLint doesn't appear to respect either the React plugin and/or Babel config, because the linter won't parse JSX files — it bails on each file with the (sadly, familiar) error:
    > Parsing error: This experimental syntax requires enabling one of the following parser plugin(s): "jsx", "flow", "typescript". (42:70)

    What this means is that we don't get proper linting or auto-formatting in Storybook sources, which stiiiinks. I think it might come down where ESLint is running in VS Code, because I get this error when I run `eslint  storybook/stories/**/*.jsx` from the project root but _not_ when running it from within the `storybook` directory. It might mean having to set `root: true` in `storybook/.eslintrc.js` and configuring it manually there rather than inheriting the root config.

* In GitHub Actions, `npm run lint` from the project root works just fine (!!), but ESLint flags the `sfgov-design-system` imports in Storybook with `import/no-unresolved` errors. I've worked around this by downgrading that rule to a warning. This is super confusing because `sfgov-design-system` _does_ get symlinked to `/node_modules` by npm in both environments and Storybook builds just fine. This seems like less of an issue than what's going on in VS Code.

Together, these issues make it hard to catch issues before you push to GitHub. ☹️

issue.title: BREAKING CHANGE: update breakpoints, add xs + sm
issue.body: This PR implements @coreyhunt's suggested breakpoints in DESSYS-133. It's a breaking change because it modifies existing breakpoints. Here's how it will shake out, version-wise: name | now (>=3) | 2.x :--- | :--- | :--- `xs` | `375px` `sm` | `640px` `md` | `768px` | `420px` `lg` | `1024px` | `768px` `xl` | `1280px` | `1090px` In other words, all of the old breakpoints are now larger, with `md` growing to `lg`'s old size. The following breakpoints are new. I made [this CodePen](https://codepen.io/shawnbot/pen/dyeLaoQ) to show the differences:

comment.body: Once again (as noted in #116), there doesn't appear to be a difference in the size of the generated CSS. This is clearly not right because we have two new breakpoints, which should add a slew of new utility variants. 🤨

pull_request.title: POC: components index
pull_request.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes two different solutions, both branched from the Storybook stubbing in #117: 1. I've added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. 2. I stubbed out a custom Storybook addon that provides a "Docs" panel and shows a link to the corresponding component documentation if it finds a component with a matching story identifier: If no matching component is found for the story, it shows a message explaining how to link one: On the docs side, I've set up an "All components" page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

pull_request.title: Components index + Storybook source link addon
pull_request.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes a single source of truth for our official [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which in turn powers links to and between the documentation and Storybook. ### Storybook In #117 we added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. This PR includes a custom Storybook addon that populate's a story's `sourceLink` [parameters] from entries in the component index. Currently matches are made when the story's id (e.g. `components-button--primary`) matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern (e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons), but we could be more explicit about it. If this approach turns out to be difficult or unwieldy in any way, I'm happy to nix the addon and move to using inline `sourceLink` hrefs in our code. ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: As you can see from that page, I have not yet: 1. Proposed or defined any of the values for the component "Status" column 2. Moved the Figma links into the component index ⚠️ **There are other ways to do this!** For instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter.; and/or we could link to the docs from story [parameters] and parse those out from Docusaurus. But both of those approaches are trickier to build and maintain, I think, and having a centralized list lets us do things like ensure that all of the URLs exist in the docs and stories get generated at build time, so we could (theoretically) fail a CI build if we break a component link. [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

issue.title: use tailwind safelist
issue.body:
we're trying to update our current theme build to include its own tailwind config to take the design system's preset and extend it in #1429 

tailwind's internal purge is removing all the safelisted patterns before our own purgeCSS does its thing.  tailwind used to have a `purge: false` option, [but it sounds like the `purge` option for tailwind 3 has been changed to `content` and only takes an array of glob patterns for tailwind's internal purge](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/upgrade-guide#configure-content-sources) (not 100% on this 😅 ).

[there is a `safelist` option](https://purgecss.com/safelisting.html), though, so this pr takes the purgeCss safelist and drops it in the tailwind config to honor that safelist

comment.body:
Yeah, we need to look at this more closely. I didn't realize that in Tailwind 3 they've dropped PurgeCSS, so we might actually want to downgrade to 2.x and pass the purge config as I suggested in the other PR. That has a kinda funky smell to me, though, since the "outer" PurgeCSS plugin _should_ be removing all of the things we don't use and that aren't in our safelist.

Before we make any more changes, though, can you figure out which new utilities are the source of this ballooning in size? [cssstats-diff](https://www.npmjs.com/package/cssstats-diff) might help with this:

```sh
npx cssstats-diff path/to/old/utilities.css path/to/new/utilities.css
```

pull_request.title: Bump parse-url and @lerna-lite/core
pull_request.body:
Bumps [parse-url](https://github.com/IonicaBizau/parse-url) and [@lerna-lite/core](https://github.com/ghiscoding/lerna-lite/tree/HEAD/packages/core). These dependencies needed to be updated together. Updates `parse-url` from 7.0.2 to 8.1.0
Release notes

Sourced from parse-url's releases.

8.1.0

parse-url@8.1.0

  • fix: cjs to load normalize-url /cc #58
  • fix: Include index.d.ts in package.json /cc #63
  • feat: support custom SSH username /cc #60
  • feat: improve regex pattern /cc #59

Thanks to @​privatenumber and @​briancoit for their contributions! :cake:

8.0.0

parse-url 8.0.0

Breaking Changes

  • The resource property will not contain the port, but the host one will.
  • Throw an error if the input is invalid. Hence, file paths like /home/path/to/dir will only be valid if the file:// protocol is added (file://home/path/to/dir)
  • Throw an error if the input length exceeds the maximum length (parse.MAX_URL_LENGTH), by default 2048.

Fixes

  • fix file protocol spoofing #48, thanks @​vovikhangcdv!
  • fix: support hyphens in git@ URLs (#50) #51, thanks @​crenshaw-dev!
  • fix: support dot in git@ URLS #52, thanks @​GalHalupSeaLights!

Other changes

  • build: add CommonJS distribution thanks to @​privatenumber! /cc #54 :cake:

issue.title: Bump parse-url and @lerna-lite/core

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

issue.body:
Bumps [parse-url](https://github.com/IonicaBizau/parse-url) and [@lerna-lite/core](https://github.com/ghiscoding/lerna-lite/tree/HEAD/packages/core). These dependencies needed to be updated together. Updates `parse-url` from 7.0.2 to 8.1.0
Release notes

Sourced from parse-url's releases.

8.1.0

parse-url@8.1.0

  • fix: cjs to load normalize-url /cc #58
  • fix: Include index.d.ts in package.json /cc #63
  • feat: support custom SSH username /cc #60
  • feat: improve regex pattern /cc #59

Thanks to @​privatenumber and @​briancoit for their contributions! :cake:

8.0.0

parse-url 8.0.0

Breaking Changes

  • The resource property will not contain the port, but the host one will.
  • Throw an error if the input is invalid. Hence, file paths like /home/path/to/dir will only be valid if the file:// protocol is added (file://home/path/to/dir)
  • Throw an error if the input length exceeds the maximum length (parse.MAX_URL_LENGTH), by default 2048.

Fixes

  • fix file protocol spoofing #48, thanks @​vovikhangcdv!
  • fix: support hyphens in git@ URLs (#50) #51, thanks @​crenshaw-dev!
  • fix: support dot in git@ URLS #52, thanks @​GalHalupSeaLights!

Other changes

  • build: add CommonJS distribution thanks to @​privatenumber! /cc #54 :cake:

comment.body:
For future reference: this was deploying (building on Heroku) as of f834f58, but stopped working after that. On the Actions side, I got as far as installing the `turbo-linux-64` optional dependency that Turbo needs to run in ubuntu, but at some point Turbo lost the plot and fails in the [`ci:build` script](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/b2ffad31caed7e42ac30bf6bd48333b88435a063/package.json#L15) with:

```
run failed: error preparing engine: the given task has not been registered
```

🤷

issue.title: POC: components index
issue.body: We've discussed in DESSYS-234 how to link Storybook and Docusaurus. This PR proposes two different solutions on the Storybook side, and a single solution with a couple of implementation options for Docusaurus. ### Storybook 1. I've added the [sourcelink](https://storybook.js.org/addons/storybook-source-link/) Storybook addon, which is intended to link to the _source_ code for a story via its `sourceLink` and `sourceLinkPrefix` [parameters][]. This adds a (git repo) button to the story toolbar that turns active (blue) when the `sourceLink` parameter is present. It's a bit of a hack (in that I've overloaded the meaning of "source link"), but it's simple and requires zero custom code. 2. I stubbed out a custom Storybook addon that provides a "Docs" panel and shows a link to the corresponding component documentation if it finds a component with a matching story identifier: If no matching component is found for the story, it shows a message explaining how to link one: 👉 **I would love feedback on which of these is preferable.** IMO the panel is a bit clunky, but the source link button is far from obvious, so I'm not leaning toward either. I'm also open to other suggestions! ### Docusaurus On the docs side, I've set up an [All components](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-119.herokuapp.com/components/all/) page that lists the components and links to both their documentation and storybook pages: The "Docs" panel and the "All components" page both use the same [components list](https://github.com/SFDigitalServices/design-system/blob/feature/components-index/website/components.js), which I'm proposing here as a single source of truth for the component. There are other ways we could do this; for instance, each component's documentation page could put the component metadata in its front matter, and the "All components" page would summarize those pages by extracting their front matter. 👉 **I would love feedback on this table and what it should include.** Regardless of how we do it, I'm trying to get at the idea of a central component index that links to all of the different things about that component: its written documentation, Storybook stories, Figma designs, source code, et al. It's quite possible in Storybook to write an addon that would automatically populate a story's [parameters] from entries in the component index using the same logic as the "Docs" panel addon I've made here; we would just need to agree on how those connections are made. (In this PR they're based on whether the story's id, e.g. `components-button--primary`, matches the component metadata's `story.path` glob pattern, e.g. `components-button**` for all buttons.) [parameters]: https://storybook.js.org/docs/react/writing-stories/parameters

comment.body: Okay, so @coreyhunt and @jacksongonzales have agreed that the sourcelink addon is the way to go. I'm going to scrap the custom addon and figure out how to connect the component index with the sourcelink plugin.

pull_request.title: Stub out component stories with Figma links
pull_request.body:
This addresses both DESSYS-245 (skeleton) and DESSYS-239 (Figma designs in Storybook). Check it out:

[👀  Storybook](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/)

I've attempted to stub out all of the components in [this Figma file](https://www.figma.com/file/nCDNClTAztpLol9l74QWSP/Design-System-Components?node-id=5895%3A3405), grouped by page when appropriate and with form-specific components nested separately. I took the liberty of implementing a couple of stories just to get a feel for the workflow:

- All of the [Alerts & Banners](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-alerts-banners--banner)
- All of our [Buttons](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-buttons--primary-button) with a table layout showing the matrix of (inline | block) × (rest | hover/focus)
- A few simple [Containers](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-containers--disclaimer)
- An [Icon component](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-icons--icon)
- [Keyboard instructions](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-keyboard--kbd)
- [Tiles](https://sfgov-design-system-pr-117.herokuapp.com/storybook/?path=/story/components-tiles--event-tile) were a lot of fun

### Linting challenges
One big issue is JavaScript linting (with ESLint), and it's a weird two-fer:

* In VS Code, ESLint doesn't appear to respect either the React plugin and/or Babel config, because the linter won't parse JSX files — it bails on each file with the (sadly, familiar) error:
    > Parsing error: This experimental syntax requires enabling one of the following parser plugin(s): "jsx", "flow", "typescript". (42:70)

    What this means is that we don't get proper linting or auto-formatting in Storybook sources, which stiiiinks. I think it might come down where ESLint is running in VS Code, because I get this error when I run `eslint  storybook/stories/**/*.jsx` from the project root but _not_ when running it from within the `storybook` directory. It might mean having to set `root: true` in `storybook/.eslintrc.js` and configuring it manually there rather than inheriting the root config.

* In GitHub Actions, `npm run lint` from the project root works just fine (!!), but ESLint flags the `sfgov-design-system` imports in Storybook with `import/no-unresolved` errors. I've worked around this by downgrading that rule to a warning. This is super confusing because `sfgov-design-system` _does_ get symlinked to `/node_modules` by npm in both environments and Storybook builds just fine. This seems like less of an issue than what's going on in VS Code.

Together, these issues make it hard to catch issues before you push to GitHub. ☹️

issue.title: BREAKING CHANGE: update breakpoints, add xs + sm
issue.body: This PR implements @coreyhunt's suggested breakpoints in DESSYS-133. It's a breaking change because it modifies existing breakpoints. Here's how it will shake out, version-wise: name | now (>=3) | 2.x :--- | :--- | :--- `xs` | `375px` `sm` | `640px` `md` | `768px` | `420px` `lg` | `1024px` | `768px` `xl` | `1280px` | `1090px` In other words, all of the old breakpoints are now larger, with `md` growing to `lg`'s old size. The following breakpoints are new. I made [this CodePen](https://codepen.io/shawnbot/pen/dyeLaoQ) to show the differences:

comment.body: Once again (as noted in #116), there doesn't appear to be a difference in the size of the generated CSS. This is clearly not right because we have two new breakpoints, which should add a slew of new utility variants. 🤨
